awd_titl_txt: Selection of Lengthscales in Fe-based Nanochessboards to Enhance Exchange-Coupled Ferromagnetism
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract

Permanent magnets are key components in a diverse range of technologies, most notably
in electric motors and electric generators. They are also critical to magnetic recording,
which still forms the foundation of large-scale data storage devices. To improve the
performance of magnets, new materials, new strategies, and new science are needed. One
approach towards improving magnetic behavior is called exchange coupling, in which
two different magnetic materials interact at the quantum level to create new properties
not available from either material by itself. For this to be effective, however, requires that
the materials be intertwined at the nanoscale, called a nanocomposite material. Most
research on nanocomposite materials has explored two extremes. Extreme simplicity is
provided by thin films, in which the two materials are simply thin, planar layers on top of
one another. Extreme complexity is provided by bulk nanocomposites, where tiny grains
with irregular shapes, sizes and interfaces, are mutually intertwined. This project
investigates a very special nanocomposite, called the nanochessboard, where a regular
tiling of the two materials is achieved by self-assembly, in specific combinations of
materials, simply by heating them. The resulting structure looks much like a chessboard,
but where the individual tiles are nano-sized. The Intellectual Merit of this study
emphasizes varying the materials combinations in order to illuminate how the nature of
the materials affects both their self-assembly into nanochessboards, and their ability to
exchange couple. In turn, this will provide the Broader Impacts of the study - the
important new understanding of the behaviors that can be used to define new strategies
for creating high-performance exchange-coupled magnets.

Technical Abstract

This project will select and compete lengthscales, structural vs. magnetic, using advanced
processing techniques to create refined nanochessboards in the Fe-Pd and Fe-Pt systems,
in order to better understand, control, and enhance exchange-coupled ferromagnetism.
These binary systems contain eutectoids of the form A1-- L10+L12 that result in
chessboards by pseudo-spinodal decomposition, if processing conditions are carefully
controlled. The Intellectual Merit is framed by the specific choice of alloys to be used
here, which dictates the uniaxial magnetocrystalline anisotropy associated with the L10
phase, which, in turn, selects the critical lengthscale for exchange coupling. Chessboards
are produced by cooling continuously through the eutectoid, but to gain additional control
over the periodicity, thermomechanical processing and cyclic annealing will be
investigated. The degree of exchange coupling will be interrogated using First Order
Reversal Curve analysis, which excels at revealing how magnetic phases interact. In
addition to the growth of chessboards from an initially polycrystalline A1 starting
material, monocrystalline A1 will also be grown, and then annealed under magnetic fields
or biaxial strain, to create a single-alignment-variant chessboard. This will enable better
understanding of the magnetization reversal mechanisms, as well as the chessboard
transformation itself. Real-time x-ray diffraction will be employed during chessboard
formation to better elucidate the kinetics and progression of the transformation. The
Broader Impacts of success in the proposed research would be the contribution to our
understanding of exchange-coupled ferromagnetism in bulk nanocomposite magnets, not
only including hierarchical lengthscales, but the role of phase morphology, interfaces and
strain. Improving permanent magnets is of ongoing major significance with regard to
increasing the efficiency of electric motors.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Permanent magnets are crucial for many technologies of importance to society, notably including electric motors for EV cars and in wind-turbine generators. The search is on for new magnetic materials that may exhibit strong magnetic fields but that do not contain rare earths, which can be expense and are difficult to source domestically. This research investigated metal alloys of Fe and Pd.  The focus was on a region of alloy composition (the Fe:Pd ratio) where two special phases are believed to form together. These are known as ordered phases, since the Fe and Pd atoms line up in regular configurations, and both phases are magnetic.  When two magnetic phases interact, through a mechanism know as exchange coupling, new and useful magnetic behaviors may result. But to promote this requires control of the size and shape of the phases down to the nanometer scale.  This project investigated how to do exactly that.

One major result of this research was the discovery of a new phase in the Fe-Pd alloy system. This phase was actually theoretically predicted to exist in 1938, but has never before been definitively identified in any alloy.  This finding is important in two ways, beyond just the novelty of its discovery. First, it is really difficult to identify this new phase since it shares structural attributes with the other two known phases.  The research approach use here shows how to very carefully obtain data from different methods and assess them in order to tease out the existence of this new structure. Second, the challenge of phase identification likely means that other researchers have likely formed this phase but not known it, and this may have lead to apparent conflicts or misunderstandings about the structure and magnetic properties.

This work also looked closely at key structural defects in the two-phase Fe-Pd alloys and found unusual structure to result. It was discovered that nanometer-thick layers of one phase would ‘decorate’ special, frequently-occurring types of boundaries in the other phase. This matters since some of these boundaries are believed to control the ability to switch the magnetic polarity of the material – an important technical magnetic property of permanent magnets known as the coercivity.  The complex structure of the defects found in this research are almost certain to affect the magnetic behavior.

As part of this investigation, it was shown that the composition range over which the two special ordered phases coexist is actually much narrower than previously believed. This will aid other researchers investigating this system, but it also means that routine processing of this material will be challenging and will require very precise control over the composition.

The project also revealed unusual pathways by which the material’s structure transformed during processing. These pathways give materials scientists fundamental insights into the energies and mechanisms that control how the structure evolves. In turn, the ability to manipulate these pathways is vital towards controlling and optimizing the relevant properties of the alloy for applications in modern technologies.

An example of the transformation structure in the alloys is shown in the attached image, obtained using transmission electron microscopy.

 


Last Modified: 09/24/2024
Modified by: Jerrold A Floro

Image
  • The figure shows the beautiful microstructure of Fe-Pd two-phase alloys, where each box enlarges an area of interest. These structures impact the magnetic performance of the alloy.
    Adrian Savovici and Jerrold A. Floro
    Copyrighted
    Jerrold A Floro
    Complex Defects in Fe-Pd
